TUT_001.name: What is Knowledge?
description: Knowledge is information that has been learned, understood, and can be applied.
It differs from mere information by being internalized and connected to existing understanding.
Knowledge can be explicit (easily articulated) or tacit (difficult to express).
TUT_001.notes: This is the foundational concept for understanding how learning systems work.
references: Bloom, B. S. (1956). Taxonomy of Educational Objectives
Anderson, L. W. (2001). A Taxonomy for Learning, Teaching, and Assessing

TUT_002.name: The Learning Process
description: Learning is the process of acquiring new understanding, knowledge, behaviors, skills, or values.
Effective learning involves encoding, storage, and retrieval of information.
The process is enhanced when new information connects to existing knowledge structures.
TUT_002.notes: Understanding how learning works helps optimize study strategies.
references: Craik, F. I. M., & Lockhart, R. S. (1972). Levels of processing
Baddeley, A. (2000). Working Memory

TUT_003.name: Memory and Forgetting
description: Human memory is not perfect - we naturally forget information over time.
The forgetting curve shows that without reinforcement, we lose most new information within days.
Hermann Ebbinghaus first documented this phenomenon in the 1880s.
TUT_003.notes: This explains why repeated review is necessary for long-term retention.
references: Ebbinghaus, H. (1885). Memory: A Contribution to Experimental Psychology
Bahrick, H. P. (1984). Semantic memory content in permastore

TUT_004.name: Spaced Repetition
description: Spaced repetition is a learning technique that involves reviewing information at increasing intervals.
It combats the forgetting curve by timing reviews just before information would be forgotten.
This method is far more efficient than cramming or massed practice.
TUT_004.notes: The core algorithm behind this learning system.
references: Pimsleur, P. (1967). A memory schedule
Wozniak, P. A. (1990). SuperMemo: Algorithm SM-2

TUT_005.name: Active Recall
description: Active recall is the practice of retrieving information from memory without looking at the source.
It's more effective than passive review methods like re-reading.
The effort required to recall strengthens memory consolidation.
TUT_005.notes: This is why testing yourself is more effective than just reviewing notes.
references: Roediger, H. L., & Karpicke, J. D. (2006). Test-enhanced learning
Kornell, N., & Bjork, R. A. (2007). The promise and perils of self-regulated study

TUT_006.name: Prerequisites and Dependencies
description: Learning is hierarchical - some concepts must be understood before others.
Prerequisites are foundational knowledge required to understand new material.
Proper sequencing of learning prevents confusion and builds solid understanding.
TUT_006.notes: This system tracks these relationships to optimize learning paths.
references: Gagn√©, R. M. (1985). The Conditions of Learning
Ausubel, D. P. (1968). Educational Psychology: A Cognitive View

TUT_007.name: Knowledge Graphs
description: A knowledge graph represents knowledge as a network of interconnected concepts.
Nodes represent concepts, while edges represent relationships between them.
This structure mirrors how knowledge is organized in human memory.
TUT_007.notes: The visual representation used in this learning system.
references: Semantic Networks: Quillian, M. R. (1968)
Collins, A. M., & Loftus, E. F. (1975). Spreading activation theory

TUT_008.name: Metacognition
description: Metacognition is 'thinking about thinking' - awareness of one's own learning process.
It includes planning how to approach tasks, monitoring comprehension, and evaluating progress.
Strong metacognitive skills dramatically improve learning outcomes.
TUT_008.notes: Essential for self-directed learning and study optimization.
references: Flavell, J. H. (1976). Metacognitive aspects of problem solving
Zimmerman, B. J. (2002). Becoming a self-regulated learner

TUT_009.name: Interleaving
description: Interleaving involves mixing different types of problems or concepts during practice.
Rather than blocking similar items together, interleaving creates beneficial confusion.
This technique improves discrimination between concepts and transfer of learning.
TUT_009.notes: Why this system mixes different types of content during review sessions.
references: Rohrer, D. (2012). Interleaving helps students distinguish among similar concepts
Kornell, N., & Bjork, R. A. (2008). Learning concepts and categories

TUT_010.name: Mastery Learning
description: Mastery learning requires achieving a high level of competence before advancing.
It emphasizes learning for understanding rather than just coverage of material.
Students progress at their own pace, ensuring solid foundations.
TUT_010.notes: The philosophy behind adaptive learning systems like this one.
references: Bloom, B. S. (1968). Learning for mastery
Carroll, J. B. (1963). A model of school learning

TUT_011.name: Deliberate Practice
description: Deliberate practice involves focused, goal-oriented practice with immediate feedback.
It requires stepping outside one's comfort zone and working on specific weaknesses.
Quality and focus matter more than quantity of practice time.
TUT_011.notes: How to make the most of practice sessions in any learning system.
references: Ericsson, K. A. (1993). The role of deliberate practice
Ericsson, K. A. (2006). The influence of experience and deliberate practice

TUT_012.name: Distributed Practice
description: Distributed practice involves spreading learning sessions over time rather than massing them.
Also known as the spacing effect, it's one of the most robust findings in learning research.
Even with the same total study time, distributed practice leads to better retention.
TUT_012.notes: The scientific foundation for spaced repetition systems.
references: Cepeda, N. J. (2006). Distributed practice in verbal recall tasks
Dempster, F. N. (1988). The spacing effect

TUT_EX001.name: Identifying Knowledge Types
TUT_EX001.statement: Classify the following as explicit or tacit knowledge: (1) Riding a bicycle, (2) The capital of France, (3) How to recognize a good melody
TUT_EX001.description: This exercise helps distinguish between knowledge that can be easily communicated versus knowledge that is difficult to articulate.
TUT_EX001.hints: Consider whether each item can be easily written down in a manual or requires personal experience to truly understand.

TUT_EX002.name: Applying the Forgetting Curve
TUT_EX002.statement: If you learn 100 facts today and review none of them, approximately how many will you remember after one week according to Ebbinghaus's forgetting curve?
TUT_EX002.description: The forgetting curve shows that without reinforcement, we typically retain only about 20% of newly learned information after a week.
TUT_EX002.hints: Ebbinghaus found that we lose most information very quickly, with the rate of forgetting slowing over time.

TUT_EX003.name: Designing a Spaced Review Schedule
TUT_EX003.statement: You just learned a new concept. Design an optimal review schedule for the next month using spaced repetition principles.
TUT_EX003.description: An effective schedule might be: 1 day, 3 days, 1 week, 2 weeks, 1 month. The intervals increase as the memory becomes stronger.
TUT_EX003.hints: Start with short intervals and gradually increase them. The goal is to review just before you would forget.
TUT_EX003.result: Sample schedule: Day 1, Day 4, Day 11, Day 25

TUT_EX004.name: Active vs. Passive Study
TUT_EX004.statement: Compare the effectiveness of (A) re-reading notes vs. (B) taking a practice test, for long-term retention.
TUT_EX004.description: Practice testing (active recall) is significantly more effective than re-reading for long-term retention, even though re-reading feels easier and more fluent.
TUT_EX004.hints: Consider which method requires more mental effort and which gives you accurate feedback about your knowledge.
TUT_EX004.result: Practice testing (B) is much more effective for long-term retention

TUT_EX005.name: Prerequisite Mapping
TUT_EX005.statement: Create a prerequisite map for learning calculus. What concepts must be mastered first?
TUT_EX005.description: A typical prerequisite chain might include: Arithmetic ‚Üí Algebra ‚Üí Functions ‚Üí Limits ‚Üí Derivatives ‚Üí Integrals. Each level builds on the previous ones.
TUT_EX005.hints: Think about the foundational mathematical concepts needed at each step. What would happen if someone tried to skip a level?
TUT_EX005.result: Arithmetic ‚Üí Algebra ‚Üí Functions ‚Üí Trigonometry ‚Üí Limits ‚Üí Calculus

TUT_EX006.name: Metacognitive Reflection
TUT_EX006.statement: After studying for 2 hours, how would you assess whether your study session was effective?
TUT_EX006.description: Effective assessment includes: testing yourself without notes, identifying what you still don't understand, and planning next steps based on gaps in knowledge.
TUT_EX006.hints: Focus on objective measures of understanding rather than subjective feelings of familiarity or ease.
TUT_EX006.result: Self-testing, identifying knowledge gaps, planning remediation

TUT_EX007.name: Applying Interleaving
TUT_EX007.statement: You're learning three types of math problems (A, B, C). Design a practice sequence using interleaving principles.
TUT_EX007.description: An interleaved sequence might be: A-B-C-A-C-B-A-B-C, mixing problem types rather than doing all A's, then all B's, then all C's (blocked practice).
TUT_EX007.hints: Avoid grouping similar problems together. Mix them up to create beneficial confusion and improve discrimination.
TUT_EX007.result: Mixed sequence like A-C-B-A-B-C-A-C-B instead of AAA-BBB-CCC

TUT_EX008.name: Designing Deliberate Practice
TUT_EX008.statement: You want to improve your public speaking. Design a deliberate practice routine focusing on your weakness: managing anxiety.
TUT_EX008.description: Deliberate practice for managing speaking anxiety might include: progressive exposure (small to large audiences), video recording for self-review, specific breathing techniques, and seeking detailed feedback from experienced speakers.
TUT_EX008.hints: Identify the specific sub-skill, practice it intensively, get immediate feedback, and gradually increase difficulty.
TUT_EX008.result: Progressive exposure + feedback + specific techniques + increasing challenge
